text:
“blockchain” as a handwavy way to refer to this entire domain of decentralized/cryptographic technology, not the specific data-structure or project like bitcoin, in my opinion, isn’t any more or less a scam than machine learning. whether you think ML is also a complete scam or an exciting research domain is a similar question.

As an ML researcher, and definitely not a crypto researcher, I can’t comment directly on scaminess. But a lot of really smart people base their opinions entirely on of opinions by other people, who themselves based it on opinions by other… Derivative opinions aren’t really useful signals. Lots of the discussion I see about this feels more like in-group demonstrations against the culture surrounding decentralized finance.

It’s not surprising to me that people are put off by the finance and speculative hype that’s built up around the technology. But I also see a lot of hype and speculation around ML research that is largely incidental to the merits of the research. Obviously I believe there’s valuable work, solutions to real things, to be done in ML research. Whether that value is visible to outsiders who have to look past the ML hype and certain aspects of our culture is unclear.

I am more than comfortable extending that to blockchain research area. There are real research problems and solutions and technology. There are also shitty cultural aspects, speculators, profiteers, and predators.

it is easy to look at, e.g.,  the energy cost of bitcoin as an easy opportunity to dismiss an entire field as myopic, irresponsible, and dangerous. how much energy do large ML models cost to train? massive hyperparameter sweeps of massive models where most of the work is thrown away? yes, it’s a real problem. It seems to me that people involved in the work are working on it. people interested in making hot takes and collecting hacker news clout will continue to behave accordingly. I don’t think unfounded naysaying is  any more correct than reckless overhyped speculation.

text:
It may have been a little subtle, but I do actually agree that blockchains have some use - in the limited usecase of trying to build a distributed ledger where you can't trust any individual participant.

The same goes for ML though - if you're trying to approximate some unknown function and have a lot of proven heuristics to limit your search space, you can definitely use ML to enhance your pipeline. Using only ML to do a certain task is (in the vast majority of cases) more wasteful than a mixed approach (cf. combining the two best algorithms for a task to create one "super" algorithm that's better than either)

text: Well, while I think the efforts on trying to build a "trustless environment" are noble, I also think they're misguided - mostly because in trying to build such an environment, the most novel approaches have turned out to not get rid of trust, but only shift it around and inadvertently make it harder to verify that same trust.  In the cases I know of, trust has always shifted away from two (or more) participating parties that only had to trust each other towards the implementors of the chosen software stack (which, as it turns out, are fallible like we all are) as well as the software stack itself (which turned out to be an expensive challenge).

Both ML and crypto/blockchain are often attempting technical discussions about concepts with abstract meaning like trust, authority, intelligence, and agency. These may naturally appeal to, and inform how we relate to these abstractions in our personal philosophy or political philosophy.


Especially that these technical approaches tend to suggest some optimal ideal technical solution, which is easily generalized as though it was a solution to the abstraction in other contexts.

> The problem I see is that, short of getting rid of our meat vessels, we’re not going to bridge that gap, no matter how smart the math turns out to be.
I was specifically referring to this. I think a lot of people see ML as being “solved” as being very closely related to whether our personal intelligence has any “meaning”. Likewise, your response feels suggestive that crypto problems are closely related to implications in interpersonal politics and society.

Trust an intelligence are both extremely nuanced, but they admit a nihilistic solutions. E.g. “human intelligence isn’t that meaningful”. Not  the same kind of thing you’re saying. But yours does appeal a bit to the most extreme case of usefulness. We can bridge the gap between theoretical ideals and practical consequences without requiring the real world to behave optimally.

Basically, ML produces a lot of hullabaloo about the uselessness of meatbags. Which felt like what you were getting at with implications of blockchain.

text:
To disagree with myself a bit. Researchers in technical fields tend to be poorly equipped and resistant to engaging with societal, philosophical, environmental, or ethical implications of their technical work.

It is possible to engage with technical fields in good faith while not doing so in technical terms. It is important to talk about the unintended consequences, the culture, and motivations of a field.

I feel like a lot of the cynicism is in response to the perception that everyone inside these fields are as dismissal of the implications as the cynics are of their contributions. Building and fighting straw men of each other.

The reciprocal of this challenge is that researches inside technical fields should take seriously the work of engaging with their context.
